talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: Page 65 (after line 6), at the end of Chapter 2, add:
When a business provides a consumer with a receipt or docket issued in respect of a taxable supply the receipt or docket must separately include:
(a) the price of the goods or service excluding the GST;
(b) the amount of the GST; and
(c) the total price including the GST.

In June this year, on Perth radio, the Treasurer belled the cat. The GST, he said, would be embedded in the price of goods and servicesâ`embedded', he said, but read for that `hidden' because this GST is not required by their legislation to appear on any receipts that a consumer will receive.

The amendment I am moving today protects consumers by revealing that very hidden GSTâif it gets passed by the parliament. It ensures that every time people pay the GST they will know exactly how much, so they will know exactly how deep Peter Costello has his hand in their pockets. Every minute of every day, from the cradle to the grave, there will be 10 per cent on almost everything they purchase.

The amendment also ensures that people will be saved from having to divide the price of every purchase by one-eleventh. The Treasurer says that this 10 per cent tax is a simple tax, but yesterday even he could not tell me, when asked in this chamber, what was the GST component of a grocery bill of $138.70. If the Treasurer cannot tell us what the GST component is, how can he expect the punters to know?

This is an insidious taxâbut, worse, they have hidden it. The Treasurer of this nation who introduced this tax cannot even calculate off the top of his head the GST slug. That is after excluding the 48-pack of Panadol which will not attract the GSTâbut the 24-pack willâand then working out the input tax rate for financial services. This is the greatest hotchpotch of tax legislation this parliament has seen.

If the Treasurer cannot divide by 11 to work out what the GST is, and he has been labouring for 18 months on this tax, imagine how the poor mum with three screaming kids at the checkout counter is going to work out the GST that she has been slugged for. What about the elderly going in and having to pay more for their package of goods not being able to work out this amount? There will be queues into the street waiting to get into supermarkets as a result of this confusion. If the Treasurer cannot do it, how can he expect the punters to?

The disclosure also makes retailers think twice before simply adding 10 per cent to the existing price of their products because the person will clearly see the pre-GST price and know whether the abolished taxes have been passed on. Labor's position is clear: under the GST regime consumers must have a right to know what they are being forced to pay in tax. By this amendment we will enshrine in legislation that right to informationâif the GST gets up.

Those who oppose this amendment and support a GST oppose protecting the interests of ordinary Australians. There is no middle ground in this debate. Either members in this place support the protection of consumers' interests or they do not, just as there is a clear division between Labor opposed to the GST and the coalition for it.

The vote on this amendment will show where every member in this House stands on this important issue. Hansard will show in stark terms the name of every member who votes to introduce a GST and then to hide it. How will they explain that to their constituents? (Extension of time granted) The only mention of this issue in the total tax package put forward by the government is in the explanatory memorandum to the bill. The issue, as important as it is, gets a grand total of five words in almost 1,000 pagesâfive words which say, `Displayed prices will include GST.' There is no debate, no justification for this indefensible positionâjust five cynical words.

The position of the Treasurer on this issue of hidden taxes is unbelievable and hypocritical. Before the election he sent propaganda to every home in the country complaining about the unfairness of so-called hidden taxes. Members may remember that document sent around under the Treasurer's name. It was a newsletter from Peter Costello, the member for Higgins, and it said `The hidden tax system'. I quote from it:
This newsletter reveals the unfair, hidden and complex tax you already pay every day of your lives.
It sounds like a GST to me, Mr Deputy Speaker: `unfair, hidden and complex'. That is the GST. He went on to say:
Who knows what taxes they are paying on goods? Wherever you go, there's hidden taxes.

So now we have the hypocrisy of the man introducing this legislation saying that allegedly $15 billion of hidden taxes is a terrible thing but $30 billion of hidden taxes is good for the nation. What sheer hypocrisy! He has campaigned on the basis of saying, `We'll get rid of hidden taxes,' and he has brought in the granddaddy of the lot in terms of hidden taxes. Because the GST is imposed at the retail level, it can easily be identified to consumers. This option does not exist for the wholesale sales tax.

The Treasurer could easily ensure that the GST is not hidden but he has chosen not to do so. After running around complaining about hidden taxes and claiming that they are unfair, he has now decided to hide the unfairest tax of allâ10 per cent on just about everything you buy. By his own definition, this makes the GST doubly unfair.

But the double standard does not stop there. We find in his legislation rules concerning tax invoices. They are contained in subdivision 29-C and they provide for regulations. Those regulations that can be made, according to their own tax package, could force businesses to separately disclose the amount of the GST on their business clientsâ`could'. I asked the question: will they? I got no answer yesterday. We have still got to wait and see about this great, comprehensive package.

If there is a regulation and a provision that could require businesses to identify the GST, why not have a similar one for consumers, Minister? Why shouldn't there be one for consumers so that, every time he has got his hand in your pocket, they know what he is taking out. If it is fair enough to require a provision in there for business tax disclosure, why not for consumers? That is the point we are making. That is what the amendment is about. That is what we are asking this House to vote on.

We then go to the example that is contained in the explanatory memorandum. The example used is a tax invoice made up in the name of Big Ben's Clocks, 12 Grandfathers Road, Cuckooville. This tax system sounds like it is in cuckoo land, the way it is goingâriddled with anomalies and inconsistencies and hidden from the Australian public.

There is no regulation concerning the right of consumers to be told how much GST they will be charged on almost everything they buy. I asked the Treasurer yesterday whether he would force this disclosure for business and he smugly told the Australian people to wait for his regulations. We now have further evidence of more concealed information. Everywhere you look in this whole exercise, the Treasurer is hiding something. Now he wants to hide from consumers the full extent of this GST.
What does business think about the proposal of the Treasurer? John Dahlsen, Chairman of Woolworths, the second largest retailer in the country, is reported as sayingâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWe will be rejecting this amendment proposed by the member for Hotham. It is typical of the Labor Party to want to prescribe something that is going to cause more paperwork, more costs and more hardship, particularly for small business.

speech.para: I am advised that under subdivision 29-C, subsection 29-70, which refers to tax invoices, consumers will have the option of asking for a tax invoice. They will be able to ask for a tax invoice. The member for Hotham continues to twist and turn the facts as it suits him in order to place more of a paper burden on small business and more of a paper burden on business generally, at the cost of the consumer.

If we want to talk about hidden taxes, what we should talk about is the wholesale sales tax. Why talk about the wholesale sales tax? Because if you were going to start from scratch to create the most difficult, complicated, burdensome hidden tax, you would start with the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax. Not only do you not know what the individual tax rates are, but you do not know to what goods they are going to apply. What you can say with absolute certainly with the GST is this: one-eleventh of what you pay will be the GST. But under the Labor Party's rules it could be anywhere from one per cent to 100 per cent, depending on the make-up of the product, depending on the way that it is distributed, depending on the substance of the products within the definition of the wholesale sales tax. It could be any amount. When the Labor Party, in their own unctuous and unique way, talk about the application of what they define to be the revelation of a hidden tax, they start with a great knowledge base. The great knowledge base is the system that they have created, which they have stood up for the last three days in this House and defendedâthat is, the hidden wholesale sales tax.

I defy any consumer in Australia to tell me, at an immediate instance, how much wholesale sales tax they are paying when they go to Woolies and buy a product. Is the wholesale sales tax price passed directly on to the consumer, does it become a retail tax or is it watered down in the process from wholesale to retail? That is the question they have to ask.

They might be paying, in the case of an individual product, say, 12 per cent wholesale sales tax on that product. When they go to the counter to pay for that product they may be paying 10 per cent of the retail price or maybe 14 per cent of the retail priceâwho knows? Yet the unctuous Labor Party stands up here and seeks to try to impose further paperwork, further burdensome processes, on small businesses, which, at the end of the day, have to pay for them out of their bottom line.

We are into transparency: every time you go into a shop, one-eleventh of the price you pay will be the GST. It might not be the 42 per cent under the Labor Party, it might not be the 37 per cent under the Labor Party, it might not be the 22 per cent under the Labor Party, it might not be the 12 per cent under the Labor Party, it might not be the 15 per cent under the Labor Partyâgiven that distortions are created on the way to the retail endâbut what you know with certainty is that the Labor Party is the strongest advocate of more burdensome paperwork for small business.

What you know with certainty is that the Labor Party is the creator of hidden taxes. It is the defender of hidden taxes; it is the greatest advocate of hidden taxes. The Labor Party has a lot to be answerable for in their defence of the wholesale sales tax system. We are going to vote against it because we are against more paperwork for small business and we are against the confusion and uncertainty of the current wholesale sales tax system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThat was an interesting intervention by the minister. He will need to go and check what he said and perhaps come in and correct the record, because he said in his intervention that consumers will be given the option of getting the GST disclosed to them. By what mechanism does that occur, Minister?
âThe regulations. We have already told you.

âThe regulations simply say `could', and we still have not got an answer from this government as to whether the regulations `will'. The critical point I make is that an invoice, as defined in your own legislation, is an obligation to pay. A receipt is proof you have paid. Therefore, a receipt is not an invoice, Minister.

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIf you are changing the definition, I would like you to get on your feet and tell me you have changed the definition. If what you are now saying is that the regulations could provide for all receipts at supermarkets and at every other purchase point to include the GST, that is an improvement because it is in the direction of our amendment. Then what we want is a guarantee that you will require it in the regulations, and that is what our amendment seeks. But don't you come into this place and try to pretend that there is an option there to protect consumers, because there is not.

speech.para: As the legislation stands, there is only a provision for an option, not a guarantee, in relation to tax invoicesâinvoices that are sent from someone to another saying, `You, Joe Hockey, owe me this.' That is what an invoice is; that is not what a receipt from a supermarket cash-out counter is. A receipt is proof you have paid, because your obligation to pay is the fact that you have wheeled those things through in the trolley, you have had them rung up on the cash register, you have seen the price, you have paid it and you have got your receipt. It is proof of payment; it is not an invoice. That is where you have got it wrong, Minister, and that is where our amendment will fix it up.

Let me just go back to a point I did not conclude before. It is not just Labor that is calling for this, it is not just Labor that is saying consumers should know every time you have your hand in their pocket taking tax out. Every minute, every day, cradle to the grave, they want to know how much. They cannot be expected to become mathematical wizards, dividing everything by 11 every time they walk into a place. Get up and tell meâI will throw the numbers to you off the top of my head if you get up next timeâhow easily you can divide by 11. You expect the punters to do that, you expect the elderly to do it, you expect kids going into shops to do it. What are you going to doâissue them with calculators? Is it your industry development program for the technology industry to issue people with calculators so they know what one-eleventh of everything they buy is? One- eleventh is being taken by this government every time a purchaser pays.

It is not just Labor arguing about this: the chairman of the second largest retailer in the country, Mr John Dahlsen, is saying Woolworths want the GST to appear as a separate item on dockets, rather than being hidden. Why does he want it? Clearly, because Woolworths are concerned that, under the Treasurer's hidden tax proposal, they would bear the brunt of consumer anger because of the unfair price rises that the GST will bring. And it is not just Woolies. Bill Healy of the Retail Traders Association in New South Wales says the RTA wanted the 10 per cent GST to be levied separately at the point of sale rather than being built into the ticket price.

The Treasurer wants to shift the blame for his decision to retailers. It is interesting that, since the last election, the Treasurer has also taken consumer affairs into his portfolio. The protector of consumers is now going to hide a tax from them that he is going to impose every time they go in to buy something. The consumer groups want this tax disclosed; Labor wants this tax disclosed. That is why we are proposing this amendment. It is not complex. If the minister at the table is so confused as to what has to happen, no wonder the public is confused.

We want to make sure that, if we get the GST, it is up there in lights, reminding people every minute of every day, on every item and every service that they buy, that this government has got their hand in their pocket, taking 10 per cent out. They will know how much, they will know who is doing it and they will know who is opposing it. Labor is opposed to this tax, Labor is opposed to it being hidden, and the amendment should be supported. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe government will certainly be opposing this amendment. The argument put forward by the member for Hotham would be laughable if this matter were not so serious. Labor has had a wholesale sales tax hidden in this country for years and years. When you go to the supermarket, you do not know whether you are paying 12Â½ per cent, 22Â½ per cent or 45 per cent.

speech.para: The Labor opposition do not understand small business. They hate small business. They ran this economy into the ground for 13 years. They destroyed thousands of small businesses. I know, because I was involved in small business. Somehow I managed to survive, but many of my friends and colleagues did not. Part of the reason was the unwieldy paperwork, the wholesale sales tax and the interest rates that were up around 22 per cent. The skyrocketing inflation destroyed small businesses.

We want to introduce fair, simple GST tax reform. It will be a simple and fair system of taxation in this country. Everyone will know how much tax they will pay on itemsânot like it is now. They do not know what they are paying. The member for Hotham said that the government will have their hands in the pockets of consumers, taking tax. For 13 years, every single day, the Labor government had their hands in the consumers' pockets. In 1993 they promised tax cutsâthe l-a-w tax cutsâand as soon as they got back into government they sneakily and underhandedly increased wholesale sales taxes. They did not say a word about it; they just snuck them in. They went from 20 per cent to 22 per cent and from 30 per cent to 32 per cent. Not one word was said to the consumers about the wholesale sales tax that they were paying. Where was the compensation for the elderly pensioners in my community?
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! I remind the honourable member for Robertson that we are discussing the amendment, not the general bill. He should try and direct his remarks to the content of the amendment.

âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will direct my remarks to the contents of the amendment. The exact point I was trying to make was that the wholesale sales tax was not shown on retail dockets, was not disclosed. Now we have the hypocrisy of the Labor opposition in coming in here and putting forward an amendment like this.

speech.para: Mr Lee interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âEveryone knows the amount of the GST. We have put forward the amount of the GST. Everyone knows what they will be paying. The hypocrisy of the Labor opposition! When they were in government they hid the wholesale sales tax and did not disclose it. They did not let people know the amount. Now that they are in opposition they come forward with this sort of amendment to say that it should be disclosed.
âIt should be disclosed.

âIt is being disclosed. We have just been through an election campaign where the government put forward its tax policy and told the community in an open and fair way what we proposed to do to take this country forward and help small businesses. Right through the election campaign we had the type of attack that the opposition is throwing at me today. There was the scare campaign they put out through the electorate, the misinformation that they distributed throughout the election. When you have a marginal seat, you are aware of what is going on. I am just thankful that the Australian community saw through that misinformation. They appreciated the fact that the government were prepared to be honest and fair enough to put to the Australian community exactly what we proposedâa fairer tax system which will allow this country to go forward and allow small businesses to develop and employ more people.

speech.para: The pensioners in my electorate and throughout Australia will know exactly what they are paying, unlike what happened with the hidden wholesale sales tax which the Labor government kept putting up. There was no compensation whatsoever for that. They hid it all the way along. The hypocrisy of the Labor opposition to come in here with an amendment like this! (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to expose the government's breathtaking hypocrisy on this issue of hidden taxes. I can reveal that the Premier of Victoria must be watching this debate in Victoria on a monitor. At the very moment that the shadow Treasurer was on his feet today, the Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, supported the proposal to list the GST as a separate cost on dockets. We agree wholeheartedly with the Premier of Victoria.

speech.para: In response to the government's suggestions that we are in favour of a paperwork burden and against small business, I wish to draw to the attention of the House the government's own document, `Regulation Impact Statement for the Introduction of a Goods and Services Tax', which confirms that, in its first year of operation, there will be 1,400,000 GST registrations and that the numbers are expected to grow by about 200,000 in the following year. At present, 75,000 businesses pay wholesale sales tax. So the number of businesses paying this tax, bearing this paperwork burden, will grow from 75,000 to 1,400,000 and, in the next year, to 1,600,000. Their hypocrisy is stunning.

On 25 June, the Treasurer was askedâI think this resolves the question of whether the government is going to move on this or notâwhether perhaps the GST could be shown on dockets. He said that his GST would be:
. . . embedded in the price . . . just as a goods tax is embedded in the price.
In other words, they will not be changing this. I can confirm that. Then they put out their $17 million taxpayer funded propaganda.

talk.start.para: â$20 million.
â$20 million? It is going up all the time. I am sure it is $20 million. Treasurer, I invite you to confirm that number. I am sure you will be able to.
âNo, it's not.
âThe Treasurer will not respond to the member for Rankin.
âOn that propaganda, the Treasurer said:

speech.para: This newsletter reveals the unfair, hidden and complex taxes you already pay everyday of your life.
We will see a doubling of taxation under the goods and services tax compared with the wholesale sales tax. In other words, there will be twice as much hidden tax unless this amendment gets up.
It is quite clear that there is widespread community support for this amendment. In the Australian on 24 August, the Australian Consumers Association was reported as follows:
The Government should change its position so that the GST should be displayed in the prices of goods.

It is an entirely sensible proposition from the Australian Consumers Association. Woolworths is a fairly substantial business around Australia. They are reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 November as saying:
. . . the purchase price and tax should be shown separately on the docket.

Finally, the executive director of the Retail Traders Association of New South Wales, Bill Healey, said that consumers would have to have faith that most retailers would levy the price changes honestly. He said the issue was one of the reasons the RTA wanted the 10 per cent GST to be levied separately at the point of sale rather than being built into the ticket price.

So here we have itâthe Premier of Victoria, the Retail Traders Association of New South Wales, Woolworths and the Australian Consumers Associationâthey all, quite correctly, want this government to agree to reveal the impact of this GST on the dockets at the checkout. This is an entirely reasonable proposition. We are at a loss to understand why the Treasurerâwho says, `We have got this great plethora of hidden taxes'âwill not agree to make his own tax visible by putting it on the docket. It is an entirely reasonable proposition and he should agree. I would be very happy to hear him agreeing to this amendment today.

talk.start.para: âThe government rejects this amendment. Obviously it is a stunt which was brought into this parliament with all of the flurry and abuse that the member for Hotham could work himself up to, to move it and to do it in his uniquely furious way. But, of course, it is an absolute stunt. Why is it a stunt, Mr Deputy Speaker? Well, let me make this point.

speech.para: The Labor Party introduced wholesale sales tax in the 1930s. From 1930 to 1998 did the Labor Party for one dayâfor one dayâinsist, by law, that the wholesale sales tax component of a good be shown at the checkout?
Mr Snowdon interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe member for the Northern Territory has been called to order many times. I caution him to be silent.

âThe Australian Labor Party introduced wholesale sales tax in 1930. From 1930 to 1998 did the Australian Labor Party for one dayâfor one single dayârequire by law the wholesale sales tax to be shown at the checkout counter? No, not for one single day. They come in here today and say, `68 years of our failure should now be swept aside and the government should do something that we didn't do for one day in 68 years.'

speech.para: Let me put it another way. Did the Labor Party, for all of the period that it was in governmentâthe 13 years of Labor governmentâinsist that every petrol station issue a receipt showing the price of the petrol and the price of the excise? Did it, for one day? Did it have a law for one single day? Or does it come into this parliament today and say, `Hereafter, every petrol station must give you a billâone bill or twoâwhich shows both the price of the petrol and the petrol excise'? Did it say that for one day? No, of course it didn't. After 68 years and after 13 years of government, this is just an absolute stunt and the Labor Party knows it.

Yesterday we had another blow up in the face of the shadow Treasurer. He walked into question time yesterday and said, `Tell us what the GST would be on a $138 supermarket purchase,' to which I said, `One-eleventh' straight off the top of the head. He said, `Oh, but do the division. Unless you can do $138 divided by 11 in your head you don't actually know the answer.'

Mr Deputy Speaker, let me give you a question that no person could possibly answer: what would be the wholesale sales tax on $138 worth of supermarket purchases? I ask the shadow Treasurer to go to the dispatch box and tell me. You can tell me in a fraction, if you like. Give me a fraction. What would be the wholesale sales tax on $138 of supermarket purchases? You could not answer it. The only way you could possibly answer it would be to know every single item in the basket and every single rate. You would then have to apply an economic model to get the embedded cost and you would come out with some kind of estimate. But stand up, shadow Treasurer, and tell usâwhat is the wholesale sales tax on $138 of supermarket purchases? Just go to the dispatch box. I will take it in a fraction. I will take it in a percentage. I will take it in dollars. I will take it any way you want to do it. But you just walk to the dispatch box and do it. It is impossible to do, because you need to know every item and every price on every wholesale sales tax list.

Let me tell you about Labor's wholesale sales tax. The Labor Party says, `Don't tax an antique gold-plated fountain pen, but do tax pens and crayons at 22 per cent.' That is Labor's tax. The Labor Party says, `Don't tax lobster, but do tax biscuits at 12 per cent.' The Labor Party says, `Don't tax a toothbrush, but do tax toothpaste at 12 per cent.'
Opposition member interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âLet me ask you: in your basket, did you have one pack of toothpaste or one toothbrush? Because unless you can tell me the answer to that question, you cannot tell me what wholesale sales tax is. The Labor Party says, `Tax knitting needles at 22 per cent, but knitting wool at nothing.' What is the logic in that, Mr Deputy Speaker? You have a complex system riddled with different rates. Nobody knows what it is. The Labor Party never insisted that mandatorily it be put on every bill. This is an absolute stunt and the government will reject it.
âI remind all members that we are debating the amendment and their remarks should be addressed to the content of it, including the Treasurer.

âMr Deputy Speaker, you always know when you have got the Treasurer, because he shows it. He has come in here today because he got tricked up yesterday. Any originality in his approach today? No, but he has to throw the same question back to me.

speech.para: I will tell you thisâand it is important for the backbench to understand thisâthis is the difference between Peter Costello and Peter Reith. As much as we cannot trust Peter Reith, he has got a hide like a rhinoceros. He never shows it; he never shows discomfort; he never gets sucked in. But this bloke, the guy with the glass jaw, the bloke that is dragged into this placeâyou know when you have got him, because he shows it. He is so transparent. He is so preening of himselfâalways looking up to the gallery, always smirking and grinning, always into the stunt. But here he is; he would not even come into this place during debates on these issuesâhe spent only 58 minutes introducing the most complex piece of legislationâ

talk.start.para: âI raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I ask you to bring the member for Hotham back to the issue of the debate. He seems to be digressing quite strongly.
âI thank the honourable member for Robertson. Resume your seat. The honourable member for Hotham will of course address his remarks to the contents of his amendment.

âI will, Mr Deputy Speaker. The reason this amendment is important is that consumers deserve to know what the Treasurer is taking out of their pockets every time they purchase. It is very interesting that he is not just the Treasurer of this nation; he is also minister for consumer affairs. What minister of consumer affairs anywhere in the world would introduce legislation by which consumers had their taxes hidden? But this Treasurer has. He is a world first minister for consumer affairsâhiding the tax that he is imposing on the very consumers that he is supposed to be protecting. This man is a hypocrite, because this man campaigned to get rid of the hidden taxesâ
âThe honourable member for Hotham will withdraw that statement.
âI will withdraw if he takes offence.
âNo, as the chair it is my responsibility.

âI withdraw. This man campaigned on the basis of getting rid of hidden taxes and now he has introduced a new one. He has introduced a new one that will yield twice the revenue. He has introduced a new one that covers every good and service practically in this country. And there is no point talking about the simplicity of the 10 per cent GST, because even he could not divide by 11. How does he expect the mums and dads to do it? How does he expect the elderly to do it? He could not do it, so how can the punter be expected to do it? This is a Treasurer without consistency, without commitment to his portfolioâ
âI raise a point of order. When Mr Speaker took the chair at the start of this parliamentâ
âWhat is your point of order?
âhe mentioned scorn and derision. The member for Hotham has made a vicious attack on the Treasurerâ
âThere is no point of order. Resume your seat.

âThis amendment has to be passed because we have to do the job the minister for consumer affairs will not do. We have to protect consumers. We have to show what this tax is worth, because the government will not.
âOrder! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the bill has expired. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Mr Costello:
That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI have a number of amendments. We are required to move them sequentially as a result of the government bungling the way they have brought forward this package. To give some indication as to the duplicity of this government, the night before yesterday we had an agreement about times for this debate that would have enabled more time for us to speak. That was broken within 24 hours unilaterally by them insisting upon a new order of business being introduced at 9.30 a.m. today.

speech.para: We have the position where there are nine of these bills before the House, three of them we support or, depending on what happens with one of our second reading amendments, four we could support. Because the government is requiring us to vote for them in a block in one motion, we are forced to oppose them. I made approaches through the office of the Leader of the House to try and get procedurally a separation out of those four bills. I think it is important to demonstrate that there can be agreement on both sides of the House about sensible tax reform, and we do support three of these bills and maybe a fourth bill subject to the debate.

However, they are not letting us vote with them. They are not letting us demonstrate support for their position. Why won't they do it? Why are they so hung up on the stupidity of this procedure that they will not allow us to do it? This highlights the frustration the opposition has with the way this government manages the affairs of the House, particularly on such an important package of measures as this.

There is a package of nine bills here. I will do what I can in the time that I have leftâonly 10 minutesâto go through the six amendments, because I understand that the Speaker requires them to be read in. I am not sure whether time permits me to do that, but I will do my best. The first of these bills is the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâExcise) Bill 1998 . This bill imposes a new 10 per cent tax on almost everything. On behalf of the opposition, I move the amendment to A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâExcise) Bill 1998 :
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:

(1) condemns the Government specifically for its proposed excise imposition and for seeking to impose a GST on Australian families which will inevitably rise over time as it has risen in almost every country in which a GST has been introduced; and
(2) condemns the Government for attempting to deceive the Australian people that there is a constitutionally valid mechanism which will ensure that the GST rate will not rise over time".

The next bill is A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâCustoms) Bill 1998 . This bill makes it a custom to pay 10 per cent on almost everything every time you fork out money from the cradle to the grave, turning a new 10 per cent tax into a new custom in this country, but not telling people the amount.

talk.start.para: âI am loath to interrupt the honourable member for Hotham, but the chair would have no objection if you wished to move your amendments in the terms circulated if that would suit your convenience.

âThat is very kind of you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will go through them, because I think the amendments are important in themselves, but if I run out of time in the minuscule time that is available to us, I will adopt your course of action. In relation to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâCustoms) Bill 1998 , which makes it a custom to pay 10 per cent, I move the following amendment:

speech.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:

(1) condemns the Government specifically for its proposed customs imposition and for seeking to impose a GST on Australian families which will inevitably rise over time as it has risen in almost every country in which a GST has been introduced; and
(2) condemns the Government for attempting to deceive the Australian people that there is a constitutionally valid mechanism which will ensure that the GST rate will not rise over time".

The third bill is the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâGeneral) Bill 1998 . This bill puts a huge new imposition on the Australian public and on Australian families. It imposes a 10 per cent tax on almost everything they buy. Every time they buy a good or a service, the government will have its hand in their pockets taking out one-eleventh. That is what this bill imposes on the Australian public. I move the amendment to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâGeneral) Bill 1998 :
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:

(1) condemns the Government specifically for its proposed tax imposition proposal and for seeking to impose a GST on Australian families which will inevitably rise over time as it has risen in almost every country in which a GST has been introduced; and
(2) condemns the Government for attempting to deceive the Australian people that there is a constitutionally valid mechanism which will ensure that the GST rate will not rise over time".

The next bill is A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Administration) Bill 1998 . This bill imposes a huge administrative burden on at least 1.4 million small businesses and family businesses, turning them into government tax collectors and burdening them with an administrative nightmare. That is what this bill does. I move the amendment to A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Administration) Bill 1998 :
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:

(1) condemns the Government for seeking to impose a huge new unnecessary taxation compliance burden on Australian small business which will involve, inter alia, large start-up costs, significant ongoing costs, an erosion of the competitive position of small business relative to big business which are not nearly compensated for by the claimed cashflow effects of the GST; and
(2) condemns the Government for introducing legislation which is very complex which adds to the complexity of the tax system, rather than simplifying the system".

The next bill that I propose to move an amendment on is the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Transition) Bill 1998 . This bill involves Australia making a huge transition from being the strongest economy in the world; an economy which is served by a taxation system which was developed, changed and reviewed by successive Labor governments over 13 years, producing an economy in which we fundamentally changed the structures, the approach and the strength of the nation with low inflation. We did it with a tax system that, from time to time, needed review and repair, but we made those reviews and repairs without a GST.

We are now being asked to make a transition from being the strongest economy in the worldâno system is `broke' here. The IMF says that this economy has performed well over the past seven years, and Labor was in power for two-thirds of those years. This government inherited a system that even it could not muck up in a hurry. This bill will commence the process of mucking it up. This bill is unfair; this tax is unfair. It is bad for the economy; it is bad for jobs. I move the amendment to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Transition) Bill 1998 :
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"the House condemns the Government for imposing complex, anomaly-ridden transitional arrangements concerning the GST on Australian business which will inevitably involve competitive distortions and costly compliance burdens".

I have only one amendment in relation to the next group of four billsâA New Tax System (Fringe Benefits Reporting) Bill 1998 , A New Tax System (Medicare Levy SurchargeâFringe Benefits) Bill 1998 , A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Bill 1998 , and A New Tax System (Australian Business Number Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998 âand that is an amendment to A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Bill 1998 . I move the amendment to A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Bill 1998 :
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) condemns the Government for not going far enough in its tax package in cracking down on tax avoidance;

(2) calls on the Government to tighten the legislation and administration of the Prescribed Payments System (PPS) system to ensure that only genuine self-employed people are within the PPS system; and
(3) condemns the Government's failure to introduce legislation abolishing provisional tax".

Our complaint here is simply that this bill does not go far enough. We agree with it as far as it goes, but we believe it should go further. As I said at the opening of the debate on this particular group of bills, there is a lot in common between both sides of this House on what is needed for taxation reform. We should have been entering into sensible debate and dialogue to get agreement on how we can repair the current system. We think that it can be repaired; we think it can be reviewed. We think it can be done sensibly and all of it without introducing a GST. This government has given no opportunity for such a debate in this chamber. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAre the amendments seconded?

I will also make a comment, given that the government has moved so quickly in this place once again to deny the rights of members of parliament to debate what it maintains is the most far-reaching and important piece of legislation dealing with taxation reform introduced into this place. If, in fact, it was so important to it, one would have thought more hours would have been made available to us all to debate this matter.

speech.para: I will make specific reference to a couple of bills that are a part of this package. The simple fact is that there are elements of this package which the opposition agrees with, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said. In respect of the effect the GST will have on small business, let me say this: in the course of the last parliament I went around Australia, as the shadow minister with this portfolio responsibility, talking to small businesses. They said that the last thing they needed, particularly in micro-business, was an impost on them in terms of the amount of bookkeeping that would be required and the additional hours they would have to put in after a long day at the office, at their work or at whatever they were doing, just to maintain the records so that the tax police from the Australian Taxation Office would not be on their case all the time. The simple fact is that small business do not want this sort of taxation regime. As the Leader of the Opposition has said, Labor has never shied away from taxation reform if it was necessary.

subdebate.1.para: Billâby leaveâtaken as a whole.

talk.start.para: âI appreciate being able to speak briefly on this legislation. As agreed, because of the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, in six minutes time I have to make a presentation elsewhere in this building.

speech.para: This is the second leg of the tax reform package which delivers the transport fuel tax cut worth $3Â½ billion to Australiansâwherever they live in Australiaâto the Australian economy, to exporters and to consumers in rural and regional Australia. It is the breakthrough which I have worked for over many years and which I thought we could get close to in the lead-up to the 1993 elections.

It is a privilege to stand here as a member of the coalition federal government with a mandate to deliver a new tax system: a goods and services tax; the abolition of wholesale sales tax; and the abolition of a huge amount of diesel fuel excise tax right across this country.

I point out to the House that the diesel fuel exciseâthe transport fuel taxâreductions provided for in this legislation will apply not only in respect of road, important as that is, but also in respect of rail operations. The diesel fuel is consumed by the Australian railway systems, which are variously government and private enterprise railways, across the big system of Queensland, a narrow-gauge system, and the systems of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, as well as a private enterprise rail, including iron ore and coal haulage, where it has not been electrified.

This measure will be a huge boost for rail transport as we enter the beyond 2000 period and it is one which has been long overdue. Governments on both sides of this parliament have hit hard against rail over the years. They have applied to rail a diesel fuel excise tax regime which was very unfair. I am proud of the fact that, as part of the tax reform package, there is now to be a huge reduction in fuel excise applying to rail. Equally, there is going to be a big reduction in fuel excise applying to road. That will give consumers across country Australia and exporters right across Australia a chance to have a far more effective approach and a lower cost transport system to apply upon the implementation of this tax reform package on 1 July.

The first leg of the fuel equation was delivered under subdivision 123-A and division 123, which deals with diesel fuel credits, in a new tax system bill. The second leg comes with A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax ImpositionâExcise) Bill. I note that the opposition has previously moved some amendments in relation to the excise bill. I reiterate that the government stands absolutely behind this part of the package which gives the country areas of Australia a fair go, at long last, in relation to transport fuel taxes.

I note that the Democrats have already signalled out for particular opposition the tax system changes in respect of diesel fuel. They have not done their homework on this. The more efficient you can make rail in this country, the more contribution you can make to the greenhouse equation. The more efficient you can make road in this country, again the better it is for the greenhouse equation.

I recognise that over the years the Democrats and others have pursued a particular agenda with regard to pollution, environmental considerations and the like. The bonus of our tax reform package, and one of the absolutely core parts of that package, is the transport fuel tax reform, because that will help us along the pathway of a more efficient transport system and give people living beyond Mildura and Mount Isa, at long last, a fair go with both the cost of supermarket goods on the shelves and the costs of exports from those regions to the ports, the airports and to the world.

I strongly commend the new tax system package of legislation going through the House of Representatives this day and I particularly commend the transport fuel tax reform. I am proud of it, the Treasurer is proud of it and the government is proud of it. It is long overdue.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 4, page 2 (line 12), omit "10%", substitute "0%".

I move this amendment for two reasons: one to demonstrate how simple it is for this government to change the tax rate by a simple decision of the parliament to change the rate which they said was locked in by the so-called `fantastic mechanism', to quote the Treasurer; and, second, to reinforce the point that, if we have already started to see the government, under pressure, agree to extending the exemptions to the GST, why not take it to the fullest extent and exempt everything? What they could have on the books is the technicality of a GST and no rate.

I want to go to this issue of the lock-in of the mechanism because this was heralded with great triumph by the Treasurer when his package was announced. He referred to it, and I mentioned the words before, as a `fantastic mechanism' for making sure that the rate once struck is locked in. But where is this fantastic mechanism in the legislation? The only reference one can find in the 1,000 pages of bill and explanatory memorandum is contained in clause 1-3(b) which says:
The Parliament acknowledges that the Commonwealth:

(b) will maintain the rate and base of the GST in accordance with the Agreement on Principles for the Reform of Commonwealth-State Financial Relations endorsed at the Special Premiers' Conference in Canberra on 13 November 1998.

So here we have this fantastic mechanism being based on an agreement on principlesâthe principles of which still have to be thrashed out and which, when I asked the Treasurer in this parliament where his mechanism would be, he said we would have to wait on.

What is he hiding? If in fact he has got this fantastic watertight mechanism developed, why isn't it in his legislation? Why isn't it the subject of scrutiny in the Senate where the inquiries are taking place? We know this government will not answer the question. But the issue is: where have they guaranteed the lock-in?

To demonstrate how simple it is to change the rate, all that is required is a bill to be introduced into this parliament. In the schedule to that billâcalled a taxation reform act 1999âis a two-line entry. The first is to repeal the part that levies the rate at 10 per cent and, secondly, to omit `10 per cent' and substitute `15 per cent'.

Let us not have any of this nonsense about the veto powers. A simple act of parliament will increase this GST. Why is it so simple to do it? Because we are demonstrating it here today. We are demonstrating by an amendment that you can turn the rate from 10 to zero. It is validly before the parliament, and the parliament will decide whether it gets up. Remember that Labor will be voting against the GST and the coalition will be voting for it. There will be 10 per cent on almost everything you buy. From the cradle to the grave, there will be a new 10 per cent tax on everything.

That is what they want to impose, and they will have you believe that the rate will not increase. Do not believe them. Do not believe them because the rate can be changed by a simple act of this parliament. If anyone doubts that this can happen, of the 25 countries that have introduced a GST, 22 have put it up. And another oneâSwitzerlandâis about to put its up. Do not believe them when they say that the rate will not rise.

We are still looking for the `fantastic mechanism' of lock-in, and so is Jeff Kennett. Jeff Kennett has written to the Prime Minister saying, `You have dudded me, Prime Minister. You told me that there was a lock-in mechanism.' (Extension of time granted) But this is not the first time that Jeff Kennett has attacked this legislation. He did it again today by saying he wants the 10 per cent disclosed on all receipts. That is something that this government have just voted down. Not only are they imposing a 10 per cent tax; there is also no mechanism to ensure it cannot rise and there is no mechanism to identify the precise amount. This amendment should be supported.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Mr Costello:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:
(1) condemns the Government for proposing to replace the Wholesale Sales Tax with a regressive GST;

(2) notes the advantages of the WST which include no tax on services, the exclusion of necessities such as basic food, clothing, footwear, health, and building materials, flexibility, a multiple rate structure to enable differential tax rates to be applied to different goods where appropriate, low administrative costs for government, very low compliance costs for most businesses as only 75,000 taxing points are needed compared to 1.4 million taxing points for the GST;
(3) calls on the Government to undertake a review of the WST to address the perceived anomalies with a view to correcting them as the alternative to the introduction of a GST; but
(4) notes that a GST, if introduced, cannot be maintained on top of the WST, as this will result in an unreasonable increase in the indirect tax burden on ordinary Australians".

The Treasurer says this country needs tax reform. I agree with thatâthe system does need constant reform. But the simple fact is that the need for tax reform does not mean that the only option is a GST, nor does it mean that the existing tax system is broken.

Is the tax system broken? This is what is often asserted. Not according to the Treasurer, who just the other day admitted that it is not broken. Not according to the Minister for Finance and Administration, who has just released a document showing revenue $5 billion higher in the first four months of this year than in the same period of the previous year. Not according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which, just yesterday, released data showing that growth in total tax across the country in 1997-98 was 5.2 per cent, or $8Â¼ billion.

Being in surplus is a rare occurrence in most OECD countries, but not in Australia. Including this year, the Commonwealth has been in surplus for six of the last 12 years. Labor delivered four successive surpluses in the late eighties and early nineties. Now the budget is back in surplus again and is forecast to be in surplus into the foreseeable futureâall this without a GST.

The supposed notion that the sales tax base is crumbling is unsustainable. The facts demonstrate a very different story. Rather than declining, sales tax has maintained a very constant proportion of total revenue and GDP over the last decade. Australia's fiscal position is sound due to Labor's sound economic management and tax reform. Australia's tax mixâthat is, the relative share of direct and indirect taxesâhas indirect taxes at around 30 per cent of total tax revenue, comparable to the OECD average.

But the most damning indictment of the claim that the system is broken comes from new modelling released just today. According to that modelling of the government tax package, an analysis based on the Monash model:

The Treasury has asserted that a major change in the tax mix is necessary because the present array of indirect taxes will raise insufficient revenue in relation to Australia's future public sector requirements. However the Treasury provides no explicit revenue forecasts.
I underline that point again. The Treasury, according to the Monash people, provides no explicit revenue forecasts. I continue with the quote:

At this stage of our research we have found no evidence to support the Treasury's proposition. In our basecase forecasts, indirect taxes grow at about the same rate as GDP, even in the absence of increases in rates of indirect tax.

The Treasury and the government will not produce their modelling. Try as we have to get that modelling produced, they will not. They are hiding it like they are hiding so much else in relation to this package, but we will insist upon this material being made available in the Senate inquiry. But here is independent modelling debunking the assertion of the Treasurer.

In short, the system is not broke, and it is not going to break. There is no need for the large increase in indirect taxes being proposed by Mr Costello. Australia simply chooses to raise its indirect taxes in a different way from other countries. This system works well in Australia, is fairer to ordinary people and to families and should not be abandoned for a GST. The truth is that, while the coalition desperately want a GST, Australia does not need one. The Treasurer says he wants to replace a 1930s tax system with a GSTâa value added tax. But the idea of a value added tax was first advocated in the United States by T.S. Adams in 1911. He wants to replace a 60-year-old tax with an 80-year-old one. He claims that we should have a new tax for the new century, but what he is proposing is a 1911 tax. Some reform!

He forgets to point out that, in Australia's case, the transition will be harder than in other countries because we have no turnover tax and therefore no large administrative infrastructure to collect the tax from a large number of production units. But, as much as the Treasurer would like to characterise it, Labor is not about defending a 1930s tax system. Labor has already modernised Australia's tax system.

We make no apology for concentrating on equity when we reform the system, and we continue to insist that taxation reform be fair. His case is that the sales tax was introduced in 1930 and therefore it should be repealed and replaced with a GST which was developed in the 1950s in Europe. On that basis, all excise, customs duties and income taxes, both personal and corporate, would also be repealed because they all predate the sales tax. But the truth is that we do not have a 1930s tax system. Our tax system is almost unrecognisable from that of the 1930s. Successive Labor governments have constantly updated it and Labor fully modernised it through our period of office.

The 1985 tax summit agreed to significant sales tax reform, and in 1992 the sales tax legislation was substantially streamlined. Labor in government also repaired the direct tax base which was crumbling, a tax base we inherited from the man who is now Prime Ministerâbottom of the harbour, John Winston Howard. Remember him when he was Treasurerâand all those rorts, all those bottom of the harbour schemes? That is the tax system that we inherited.

Labor's major reforms include the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the petro leum resource rent tax, the taxation of foreign source income and cracking down on tax havens. Collectively, these fair, progressive measures contributed around $7 billion this year to better public services without impacting unfairly on ordinary Australians and ordinary PAYE taxpayers. Other reforms, such as the superannuation taxation regime, have further increased this contribution to around $10 billion.

The coalition oppose the vast majority of these fair, modernising taxation reforms. We all remember the now Treasurer, the member for Higgins, and his desperate attempts to block Labor's measures to crack down on tax avoidance through employee share ownership schemes. I quote him:
We've knocked off the last two and we plan to knock this one off as well. We will be opposing root and branch Labor's latest proposal.

So today we have in charge of our tax system the tax rorter's friend, now Treasurer of Australia, Peter Costello, and old Barnacle Bill from the bottom of the harbour as Prime Minister. That is who is proposing this taxation reformâand what form have they got? Appalling form.

The real issue in taxation is keeping the direct tax base in good repair. That is where the focus should be with the government, not increasing the cost of living for ordinary families. Labor has demonstrated that, if the government is vigilant in keeping tax avoidance in check, we do not need an unfair tax on necessities. That remains the case today.

The wholesale sales tax is a better tax than the GST. Its structure is very flexible and can react quickly to urgent situations. Two recent examples come to mind. When the High Court held that the business franchise fees of the states were unconstitutional, what did this Treasurer do? He used the sales tax to impose a 15 per cent surcharge on wine and other alcoholic products to recover the threatened revenue. This increased the number of rates from six to seven. Let me repeat that. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, increased the number of sales tax rates from six to seven. But it was very effective also in dealing with the unprecedented fiscal crisis confronting the states.

Were any of the states criticising the sales tax then? No. Because it helped to save their budgets in a relatively simple and effective manner. Furthermore, when some of the states threatened to renege on the uniform gun laws, what did the Prime Minister do? He threatened that a punitive level of sales tax would be imposed on certain firearms if the states broke the agreement. So, for the Prime Minister's greatest achievement in his first term, he enlisted the flexible multirate sales tax. These options are simply not available under the flat rate GST.

So sales tax has a great flexibility as a policy tool, and it has been used by both the current Prime Minister and the current Treasurer in precisely this mode. The wholesale sales tax is an input tax, just as his tax on financial services and home rentals is an input tax. A multiple rate structure in an indirect tax is not a fault; rather, it is an advantage. His input taxes, just as wholesale sales taxâthe very thing he beratesâhe now adopts in his tax package: input taxing.

Mr Costello has also criticised the seven-rate structure of the wholesale sales tax. But we should remember that the GST will have up to five ratesânil; 10 per cent; probably around four to five per cent, depending on the flow-on impact for input taxed industries; and others for luxury cars and for wine. Sales tax has seven rates, of which Peter Costello produced two, and the tax he berates he now adopts. In fact, the Treasurer is a serial taxer and a serial hypocrite to boot!

Labor believes that necessities should not be taxedâfood, clothing, footwear, electricity, gas, telephone and health care. We also believe that luxuries should be taxed at a higher rate than ordinary items. All of this can be achieved by sales tax. What should also be understood is that the flat rate GST structure proposed here is not the norm. Most countries that have a GST have a multirate structure. They believe that differing goods and services should be taxed at differing rates. Just some examples of countries with differential rates in the OECD include Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Mexico, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Swit zerland, Turkey and the United Kingdom. We should also consider the range over which these exemptions fall.

speech.para: The efficiency of sales tax is also impressive. For the 1996-97 year, almost 95 per cent of the revenue is provided by a little over 8,000 taxpayers. These firms will provide around $14 billion in sales tax this year. Contrast this with the GST that will increase the number of taxpayers from 75,000 to 1.4 million. The initial cost of the GST approach is estimated as $7,000 by the National Tax Accountants Association. This represents about $10 billion in costs in the first year, with huge ongoing costs as well.

The government claims that sales tax is a tax on manufacturing and the GST spreads the burden to the services sector. But you cannot look at these issues in isolation. The services sector will have this GST imposed on everything that they do. This is the country's fastest growing sector in terms of employment. Of the two million new jobs created in Labor's 13 years, practically every one was generated in the service sector. The GST is a tax on service industries and a tax on jobs.

Government ministers say a payroll tax is bad because it is a tax on jobs but, in the same breath, they propose a new $30 billion tax on those jobs. This is going to have interesting implications for the Ralph review of business taxation. For, while sales tax is weighted more heavily on manufacturers, miners and farmers, so are the various tax concessions and outlays measures. Last year, manufacturers, farmers and miners received $2.6 billion in budgetary assistanceâ75 per cent of total industry assistance. In proportion to its size, the services sector received just a fraction. So manufacturers are compensated for a sales tax with significant concessionsâtax expenditures. Service industries do not receive the tax concessions, but they also do not pay the tax. So the GST is going to change all of that. Service industries which will be paying 10 per cent on everything will demand significant compensation. They will be the ones pushing for the 30 per cent company tax rate goal. Note the word is `goal'. `Goal' is an even more discredited commitment than a non-core promise. These people will demand, through the Ralph re view, reductions in the company tax rate. They will argue that with the GST manufacturers will no longer need special assistance measures. It will be an interesting debate and we will be following it intensely.

This week we have witnessed the disappearance of the Treasurer's great anomaly-free tax system. We can score as many points on the GST anomalies as he can on the wholesale sales tax. But the truth is that all indirect taxes are going to have anomalies, particularly where there are exemptions. They arise when the boundaries for those exemptions are drawn. The point about sales tax is that the task of administering these issues and sorting out the anomalies does not fall to the ordinary small businessman and woman.

The wholesale sales tax does an effective job and it should not be repealed. It is a better, fairer, more efficient tax than the GST. Unfortunately, the GST has now been passed by the House despite Labor's best efforts. Labor will redouble those efforts to have the GST rejected by the Senate, but we are now presented with a series of bills which, however inadequately, are designed to compensate for the GSTâ

âI rise on a point of order.

âOrder! Both members at the table will resume their seats. Before I call the minister, I have already ruled that there is no point of order regarding agreements made informally between the parties. So if you wish to raise a point of order, it had better not be on that one.

âMy point of order is on relevance. The member for Hotham is not speaking to the appropriate bill; he is right off track. He is talking about the overall package and, therefore, I ask you to bring him back to the substance of the debate, which is an end to sales tax, which the member for Hotham is opposed to.
âI thank the minister.
âOn a point of order in respect of the arrangements for today, Mr Deputy Speakerâ

âYes.
âI have only had one call. Do you want a division or not?

âMr Deputy Speaker, this is an absolute joke. I moved this amendment.
âNo. Resume your seat.
âOn a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, and it is this: did you call for the seconder before you ruled my motion out of order?
âNo, I have no obligation to.
âYou are required to do that.

âThe rules and regulations for the House required me, at 1.50 p.m., to put the question despite the fact that you still had not finished and you still had not had somebody second your amendment. The question is: do you want a division?
